oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Longtime music teacher, Ethel Elmore
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Elmore began teaching at Eagleville School when the new building was constructed in 1917. Although the school burned in 1923, she continued to educate local youths for about fifty years. Elmore retired sometime around 1967.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Eagleville high school graduating class, 1935

Second row, standing (L to R): Roy Dowdy, Principal, (Married names are included) Gladys CarltoIi, Lola Pearl Hall, Mary T. Taylor, Mary Catherine Neal, Louise Zumbro, Edna Kelly, Geneva Stanford, and Sara Redmon. Note: These names agree with those identified with the City of Eagleville photo used in the story by Dan Whittle in his "Roamin' Middle Tennessee" column thatappeared in The Daily News Journal (Murfreesboro, TN) on Sunday, March 14, 2004. That date was after the passing of Gladys Carlton Luttrell on February, 17,2004.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Was first Eagleville school
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Sloan, Eugene
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Savage School
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rutherford County Schools Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: According to Mrs. W. H. Potila, who has done exhaustive research in the Eagleville area, the first post Civil War School established in Eagleville was the Savage School, named for the headmaster, Professor G. M. Savage and chartered in 1865. The school consisted of a building with an auditorium, a "boarding house" with rooms for girls. There was a building with ten rooms for boys and a residence for teachers. The curriculum consisted of English, Hebrew, Latin, French, Greek, German, elocution, natural sciences, mathematics, mental and moral science, penmanship, music, and bookkeeping. The school was still flourishing in 1888 when a combination catalog and school roster listed 178 students from Chattanooga, Shelbyville, Nashville, and Texas as well as Culleoka, Ruch Creek, Rockvale, Chapel Hill, Adamsville, Winchester, Fairfield, Versailles, Fayette Corner, Hickory Valley, Lone Elm, Alisona, College Grove, Luling, [and] Knoxville.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Schools
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Digital Initiatives, James E. Walker Library, Middle Tennessee State University

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Eagleville High School Students, 1963, Washington, DC
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Crick, Shirley Porrell
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Eagleville High School

Front row (L to R): Betty Lou Dyer Ettinger, Cindy McClaran Vaughn, Kathy Riggs Trout (Deceased), Marion Ann Maupin Haynes, Esther Crosslin Victory; Shirley Perrell Crick, and Patsy Rowland Reeves. Standing: Charles Blackwell, Buddy Pate, Tom Reed, Jon McCord, Kenny Snell, Don McCord, Mr. J. D. Todd, Mrs. Todd, Mrs. Elmore, Mr. U. R. Elmore, Harold Vincion, Eddie Wayne Haley, Bus Driver (name unknown)
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rutherford County Schools Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description:
EHS 1963 Senior Class, By Shirley Perrell Crick Our class, like those classes who had gone before us, sold magazines our Junior and Senior years. Our Senior year we worked the concession stands during the basketball games which added to our "Washington Senior Trip." In our particular class we had $7.00 per day on which to eat. Enough to pay for everyone's week stay from and back to Eagleville. Our transportation was a chartered a Greyhound Bus. We squeezed Lincoln's head off each pennY, making the money stretch for the "Senior Trip." Our chaperons had made the trip so many times that they knew exactly where to go and what would be the best time to arrive at each destination. We had a curfew of midnight. The girl(s) could not go out unless we had one ofthe boys with us.
One from our Class of 1963 came back and became principal of Eagleville School. Buddy Pate served as Principal from 1995 - 2004. On a personal note, I had never been any further than Nashville. It was so exciting to save and work hard to make the money for our "Senior Trip". It is something I will never forget. Since 1963 I have visited Washington and seen most ofthe places that we saw in 1963. But for a farm girl it was a really big deal to make that first trip. Our class was small and we were like family. I am truly grateful for the experience. We went in separate directions after returning from our trip. We use to get together every five years for a class reunion. We have missed a few but those special classmates will always have a special place in my heart.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Portraits, Group; Students;
Capitols
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Digital Initiatives, James E. Walker Library, Middle Tennessee State University

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Savage school attendees, [1911]
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Original photo on board and attributed to Savage by BSS; the words "Miss Ethel Elmons" is written on the back.
Savage School

Miss Ethel Elmore is in the third row from back, wearing a dark dress and standing in front of the center post. Roberta Kelley (Jarrell) is the third girl from the top in front of left post; she was born on July 18, 1896. Sallie Kelley (Hamilton) is the small girl in the left part of the fourth row; her hair is pulled back and parted in the center; Sallie is wearing a light-colored dress with a square collar; she was born in 1902.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Eagleville high school twenty-fifth annual commencement exercises
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Eagleville High School
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rutherford County Schools Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: TWENTY-FIFTH ANNUAL Commencement Exercises EaGLEVILLE HIGH SCHOOL SUNDAY EVENING, APRIL 17th 8:oo O'CLOCK. FRiDAY EVENING, APRIL 22nd 8:00 O'CLOCK 1938 Calendar COMMENCEMENT SERMON SUNDAY EVENING Processional Largo Handel Hymn "Lead on, 0 King Eternal" Lead on, 0 King eternal, The day of march has come, Henceforth in fields of conquest, Thy tents shall be our home. Through days of preparation, Thy Grace made us strong, And now, 0 King eternal, We lift our battle song. Lead on, 0 King eternal, Till sin's. fierce war shall cease. And holiness shall whisper, The sweet amen of peace, For not with swords' loud clashing, Nor roll of stirring drums , But deeds of love and mercy, The hoov'nly kingdom comes. Lead on, 0 King eternal, We follow, not with fears, For gladnes [sic] breaks like morning, Wheree'er Thy face appears, Thy cross lifted o'er us, We journey in its light, The crown awaits the conquest, Lead on 0 God might. AMEN. Scripture RUlding and Prayer Rev. J. C, Miles Chorus Serve The Lord in Youth Sermon Rev. F. A. Calhoun GRADUATION EXERCISES FRIDAY EVENING Processional (Largo) - Handel Invocation - Rev. R. C. Crosslin Class Song - Victory Song - Anthony Valedictory - Katherine Hay AddreSS - Professor L. I. Mills Presentation of Medals Presentation of Diplomas Recessional (March Militaire) - Schubert CLASS ROLL Walter Mai Bell Mary Elizabeth Clary Katherine Hay Lillian Lowe Frances Little Robbie Turner Henry Giles Walter Giles Clifford Hughes Harold Hall John Maxwell Joe McClaren Class Motto - "Tonight We Launch, Where Shall We Anchor?" CLASS OFFICERS President - Walter Giles Vice President - Harold Hall Secretary - Lillian Lowe Treasurer - Frances Little

GRADUATION EXERCISES WEDNESDAY EVENING Processional-Largo - Handel Song - Class Invocation - Rev. S.H. Parks Song - Grammar School Address - Baxter E. Hobgood Presentation of Medals Presentation of Diplomas Recessional (March Militaire) - Schubert

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Middle Tennessee Oral History Project
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A number of former Rutherford County teachers and students are included in this large oral history collection. Numerous interviewees recall Crichlow School: C. B. Arnette, Zane Cantrell, Shirley Jones, Martha Moffett, Richard Reeves, Mary Belle Robinson, and Jane Tucker. Additional highlights include interviews with educators Ruth Bowdoin, Vera Covington, Jerry Gaither, and Myrtle Lord. The collection also includes interviews with former students of Bradley Academy (Olivia Woods), Campus School (Harry Patillo), and Holloway High School (George Minter).
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Schools -- Tennessee -- Rutherford County -- History; Teachers -- Tennessee -- Rutherford County -- Interviews
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: Albert Gore Research Center, Middle Tennessee State University
Albert Gore Research Center, Middle Tennessee State University

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Road Conditions of Rutherford County, 1935-1936
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: United States Office of Education
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This map has symbols for roads (all-weather and non-all-weather) and the different types of schools ("elementary" "elementary and high school" and "high school"). The shaded area of the symbol indicates the exact location of the school. An "N" beside a symbol denotes an African American school.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: African American Schools -- Tennessee -- Rutherford County; Schools -- Tennessee -- Rutherford County -- Maps

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: United States Office of Education

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Miss Mary Hall interview: first teaching job
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Hall, Mary
oai_dc:dc.dc:contributor: Bullen, Bob, interviewer; Nunley, Joe, commentator
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Mary Hall discusses her first teaching job after World War I in a one-teacher school house. Hall had two years of college work prior to taking the job. She taught twenty-five students from first to eighth grade. One of her students was "Red" Owens, a football player at Middle Tennessee. Although Hall does not mention the name of the school in the interview, Rita Schaerer King provides the location of the school in her biography, Mary Hall: a 20th century pioneer for educational progress in Tennessee (Peabody College for Teachers of Vanderbilt University, 1993). This location matches the description of Porterfield School in Louise Houck Wisers A History of Rutherford County Schools (Murfreesboro, Tenn.: Rutherford County Retired Teachers Association, 1986).
Porterfield School
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Hall, Mary Ella, 1895-1991; Educators; Education; School buildings; Women

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Map of Rutherford County, Tenn. : from actual surveys
oai_dc:dc.dc:publisher: D.G. Beers & Co.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The map shows roads, railroads, property tract lines, tract numbers, and landowners' names. This map is mentioned numerous times in Louise Houck Wisers book, A History of Rutherford County Schools (Murfreesboro, Tenn.: Rutherford County Retired Teachers Association, 1986).
